metadata.title: Synthesis of diethylcarbonate by ethanolysis of urea: A study on the recoverability and recyclability of new Zn-based heterogeneous catalysts

Angelo, Via Cintia, 80126 Napoli, Italy Department of Chemical Sciences, University of Naples, Complesso Universitario di Monte S. Angelo Via Cintia Napoli 80126 Italy e Istituto di Cristallografia, CNR, Via Amendola 122, 70126 Bari, Italy Istituto di Cristallografia, CNR Via Amendola 122 Bari 70126 Italy f Total Research and Technolgy Fely, Seneffe B-7181, Belgium Total Research and Technolgy Fely Seneffe B-7181 Belgium ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry, University of Bari, Campus Universitario, Via Orabona 4, 70126 Bari, Italy. Tel.: +39 080 5443606; fax: +39 080 5443606. Graphical abstract New Zn-based catalysts are described that act as heterogenized or heterogeneous catalysts, with easy recovery and re-utilization with a limited or even zero Zn-leaching. For stabilizing in the heterogeneous form the catalytically active Zn centre, mixed oxides, ZIF-8 and Zn-tethered systems have been synthesized and found to sensibly reduce the leaching of Zn in solution with respect to ZnO, making possible their recovery and reuse. ZIF-8 can be used for long time of reaction, reaching high DEC yields (comparable or higher than those obtained with ZnO) without any significant loss of zinc. Keywords Alcoholysis of urea Mixed oxides ZIF-8 Zn-tethered systems Diethylcarbonate 1 Introduction The importance of dialkylcarbonates is mainly due to the large market they find in several industrial sectors such as monomers for polycarbonates [1,2], solvents for paints [3], in pesticides and adhesives [4], in the energy sector as electrolytes in Li-ion batteries [5], and in the pharmaceutical [6] and agrochemical industry [7]. Moreover, they have been suggested as fuel additives in the place of methyl-terbutyl ether (MTBE) or as gasoline component, improving the octane number and reducing the particulate emissions by 50% [8]. The synthesis of dialkylcarbonates at the industrial level is mainly based on phosgenation of alcohols [9], oxidative carbonylation of alcohols (ENIChem [10] and UBE processes [11]), transesterification of other carbonates [12]. The direct carboxylation of alcohols is an alternative that has serious thermodynamic limitations [13]. However, considering the serious drawbacks of each process, such as being poisonous (phosgenation), corrosive (ENIChem process) or explosion-prone (UBE process), having a complex reaction course, new low-cost and environmentally friendly synthetic methodologies are required. The alcoholysis of urea [14] could be an efficient alternative to the processes described above. It is a two steps process: the intermediate alkylcarbamate (Eq. (1)) is easily produced and converted into dialkylcarbonate (Eq. (2)). Eq. (2) is the rate-determining step [14a] that requires an efficient catalyst in order to obtain a reasonable yield of dialkylcarbonate. (1) H2NC(O)NH2 +ROH→H2NC(O)OR+NH3 (2) H2NC(O)OR+ROH→(RO)2CO+NH3 Several catalysts such as homogeneous transition metal complexes and metal oxides have been tested in such reaction [14–20]. Among them, ZnO has drawn particular attention, most likely because of the acid–base properties of its surface [14,17]. The role of the catalyst in the reaction has been investigated [21] in depth for the ethanolysis of urea for DEC production: it is clear that ZnO completely dissolves in the reaction medium already at 343K since it converts into the homogeneous Zn(NH3)2(NCO)2, the real active species [22]. Such a species could be formed via a series of reactions based on the decomposition of urea (Eq. (3)) that extensively occurs at a temperature above 413K. HNCO can then react with ZnO (Eq. (4)) to afford Zn(NCO)2. The coordination of NH3 to Zn(NCO)2 affords the isolated species (Eq. (5)). Water, the co-product of Eq. (4), could be used by urea to produce ammonium carbamate (Eq. (6)). (3) H2NCONH2 →NH3 +HNCO (4) ZnO+2HNCO→Zn(NCO)2 +H2O (5) Zn(NCO)2 +2NH3 →(NH3)2Zn(NCO)2 (6) H2O+O=C(NH2)2 →NH4OOCNH2 Then ethyl carbamate (EC) formed upon reaction of urea with ethanol co-ordinates via the carbonylic group to the Zn centre and undergoes alcoholysis to afford diethylcarbonate (DEC) [21b]. Therefore, according to these studies, ZnO can be considered as a precursor of the homogeneous catalyst Zn(NH3)2(NCO)2. Due to the solubilization of the latter in the reaction medium, the recovery of the catalyst is a quite complex procedure that prevents the ZnO application in continuous reactors and makes very difficult its recovery in batch processes. Several examples of Zn-based catalysts are reported in the literature [23]. Most of them are synthesized through co-precipitation/sol–gel procedures that do not allow to obtain a complete precipitation of Zn centres so that it is not possible to control the stoichiometry of the final compound [23a,b]. Moreover, there are no dedicated studies to determine the leaching of Zn during the catalytic runs. Herein, we report the syntheses of new Zn-based catalytic systems which may avoid the catalytic centre solubilization in the reaction medium allowing its recovery and reuse in other cycles of reaction or its application in flow-reactors. Innovative and solventless synthetic procedures have been used in the synthesis of mixed oxides. Three different classes of compounds have been investigated, namely: mixed oxides, ZIFs and Zn-tethered catalysts. To demonstrate the stability of the catalysts, leaching studies of Zn in the liquid phase have been carried out. Moreover, BET surface area was measured and a correlation of the strength of acid-basic sites to the catalytic activity is also discussed. 2 Experimental All solvents and reagents were RP Aldrich products. Alcohols and toluene were dried, distilled [24] and stored under dinitrogen. Complex 1 (Fig. 1 ) and Complex 1 tethered on SiO2 were prepared according to the procedure described in literature [25]. ZIF-8 was synthesized according to Ref. [26]. The obtained solid was further washed with ethanol in order to remove the soluble portion of the catalyst and reducing the leaching during the catalytic process. Solid state syntheses were carried out using a Pulverisette 7 Fritsch High Energy Milling at 700rpm. The obtained solids were then calcinated at the temperature reported in Section 2.1. The diffraction data (XRD pattern) were collected using a RINT2500 Rigaku equipment with a rotating anode generator 18kW, Cu target (normal focus) (available at the laboratories of the IC-CNR-Bari). Energy Dispersive X-ray diffraction (EDX) patterns were recorded at room temperature on a Shimadzu EDX-720/800 HS, using a 5–50kV Rh target X-ray generator and a Si (Li) detecting system. For noise reduction, the detector is cooled using liquid nitrogen. Surface characterization was done using a Pulse ChemiSorb 2750 Micromeritics instrument. The analyses of the base sites were carried out using CO2 as probe-gas using 100mg of catalyst. The samples were pre-treated under N2 at 20mLmin−1 flow and 773K. The Pulse Chemisorb was performed with CO2 gas using He as carrier gas (40mLmin−1). The TPD were performed under He flow at 40mLmin−1. BET surface analyses were done using 30% N2/70% He gas mixture. GC–MS analyses were carried out with a gas chromatograph Shimadzu 17 A (capillary column: 30m; MDN-5S; 1 0.25mm, 0.25mm film) coupled to a Shimadzu QP5050 A mass spectrometer. Quantitative determinations on the reaction solutions were performed using Hewlett Packard 6850 GC-FID (capillary column Carbowax, 30m, Ø 0.25mm). Chlorides were determined by potentiometric titration using a Metrohm 785 DMP Titrino Coulometric Karl Fischer Titrator. XPS has been used for the surface characterization of the investigated systems. XPS spectra were obtained with a Thermo VG Thetaprobe spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc., Waltham, MA, USA) equipped with a microspot monochromatized Al Kα source. Survey (binding energy range 0–1200eV, pass energy 150eV) and high resolution scans (pass energy 50eV) were recorded in the FAT analyzer mode. Nonlinear least-squares curve fitting of the detailed spectra was performed by using the Avantage software package. Quantification was obtained by peak areas normalized by acquisition parameters and sensitivity factors provided by the manufacturer, whereas the binding energy (BE) scale was set by fixing the C1s component due to adventitious hydrocarbon at 285eV [27]. Before XPS analysis, all samples were prepared by pressing the powders onto a small square of double-stick carbon tape. SEM analyses were carried out using the Alfatest Phenomworld Analitica technology. 2.1 Synthesis of mixed oxides 2.1.1 Synthesis of CuO/ZnO mixed oxide Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2g) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (1.6g) were ground together in a high energy mill for 30min at 700rpm. The resulting solid was calcined at 823K for 3h. 2.1.2 Synthesis of 0.5 In2O3/ZnO mixed oxide Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (2g) and In(NO3)2·xH2O (2.1g) were ground together in a high energy mill for 30min at 700rpm and the solid was calcined at 823K for 3h. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Si/Zn mixed oxides SiO2/0.05ZnO and SiO2/0.1ZnO mixed oxides were prepared using 0.2g and 0.4g of ZnO respectively and 3.0g of SiO2. The reagents were ground together in a high energy mill for 30min at 700rpm and then they were calcined at 823K for 3h. 2.2 Synthesis of tethered-Zn(NCO)2 system SiO2-supported tethered ZnCl2 (100mg) was put in 5mL of EtOH. A stoichiometric amount of KNCO (8mg) was dissolved in 1mL of water and added to the above ethanolic solution. The mixture was kept under stirring overnight. The solid was then separated by centrifugation, washed with ethanol (3×5mL) and analyzed. The IR spectrum revealed the presence of a signal at 2231cm−1 due to the isocyanate moiety. Such signal is shifted respect to the isocyanate signal in KNCO (2198cm−1). The EDX analysis reveals the presence of 1.4% in weight of Zn. Chloride analysis resulted to be negative. 2.3 Ethanolysis of urea for diethylcarbonate (DEC) production in batch conditions The alcoholysis of urea was carried out in a 100mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a 35cm long stainless steel tube used as refrigerant. In a typical catalytic test 0.5g of urea and 5mL of ethanol (molar ratio EtOH/urea=10:1) were used together with 0.07g of catalyst (weight ratio urea/catalyst=7:1). The reaction was carried out at 453K for 7h or longer, as specified in Table 1 . During the first 2h the inner pressure increased because of the release of NH3 that escaped the reaction vessel through the upper refrigerant, and was collected. A lowering of the pressure was then observed due to the lower NH3 release: the vapour phase was essentially made of ethanol. At the end of the reaction the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the inner liquid solution was analyzed using GC. 3 Results and discussions Mixed oxides, ZIF-8 and tethered-Zn compound were tested in the ethanolysis of urea. The obtained results are collected in Table 1. 3.1 Ethanolysis of urea using mixed oxides as catalysts Mixed oxides are known to have tunable acid–base properties that influence their catalytic activity in the direct carboxylation of alcohols with CO2 [28]. In this work we show that they behave as active catalysts in the synthesis of dialkylcarbonates, and their different acid–base properties influence the ethanolysis of urea. We have prepared binary mixed oxides containing ZnO and a second metal oxide such as CuO and In2O3: the choice of the second metal oxide was done considering those containing metals that, like zinc, are known to be active in the cleavage of NC bonds of proteins in natural metal enzymes [29]. Besides copper and indium compounds, molybdenum polyoxometalate and cobalt oxide (under examination) have also been reported in the literature to be able to cleave the peptide bond [30]. The new binary mixed oxides were tested in the ethanolysis of urea for DEC production (Table 1, Entries 1–6). Pure ZnO is used in this work as the benchmark. As shown in Table 1, the new catalysts show different properties than ZnO: the latter is “apparently” the most efficient catalyst, based on the conversion yield at the end of the first cycle. We recall at this point that catalysts 3–6 listed in Table 1 are not soluble in the reaction medium while ZnO is. ZnO behaves as a homogeneous catalyst, while species 3–6 (Table 1) are real heterogeneous catalytic species. We have thus investigated the behaviour of ZnO comparatively with that of the heterogeneous species 3–6 in order to find out the “real” catalytic properties of the various Zn-based catalysts. The first property investigated was the stability of the catalysts in catalysis and the leaching of Zn. As said above, ZnO is soluble and is recovered (ca. 40–50%) as Zn(NH3)2(NCO)2 at the end of the catalytic run. ZnO is, thus, the precursor of the real catalyst, and cannot be recovered as such at the end of the run. From a point of view, we can say that it is all “lost”. For a complete recovery of the new Zn-species it is necessary to eliminate all the solvent, very unpractical, as the residue will contain the carbonate, the carbamate and residual Zn-species. The amount of Zn leached in the reaction medium from the new mixed oxides and their capacity to act as heterogeneous catalysts (Table 2, Entries 2 and 3) depend on their composition. CuO/ZnO and 0.5In2O3/ZnO mixed oxides release ∼20% of the total zinc present in the catalyst. Si/0.1Zn and SiO2/0.05ZnO mixed oxides tend to keep zinc in the solid state. Mixed oxides are quite easily recovered at the end of the reaction and can be reused giving the same DEC yields in the cycles after the first with a minor reduction of less than 10% of the starting yield. Among those tested, CuO/ZnO shows the most interesting properties as it is robust and has a good catalytic activity better than ZnO itself (compare Entries 1 and 3 in Table 1 and Entries 1 and 2 in Table 2) per Zn-centre highly improving the Zn-utilization. XPS analyses reveals a Zn/Cu molar ratio on the surface equal to 1.3±0.3, while elemental analyses give an overall metal molar ratio 1:1. This means that copper is quite homogeneously distributed between the bulk and the surface stabilizing the Zn centres and reducing the leaching of metal during the reaction with respect to ZnO and prevents the dissolution. The surface is slightly richer in Zn than the bulk. Considering that Zn is the more active species, this can justify the good catalytic activity and moderate stability in consecutive cycles. When the reaction is carried out using the same amount of leached catalyst, a lower yield (0.86%) is obtained demonstrating that the active centres are not only in the leached portion but also is in the solid one. 3.2 Ethanolysis of urea using ZIF-8 as catalyst In order to check the potential of different classes of heterogeneous catalysts we have used Zn-imidazolate-frameworks (ZIF) [26]. ZIFs are organic–inorganic compounds characterized by zinc centres solely coordinated by the N atoms of organic linkers, namely the five-membered imidazolate (IM) units. As reported in the literature [26], ZIFs can be associated to the zeolite family thanks to MIMM angle close to 145°, which is coincident with the SiOSi angle of zeolites, although the organic components of ZIFs provide for organically lined cages and channels rather than a silicate oxide surface as in zeolites. Recently, ZIFs of different composition and structure have been synthesized, among them ZIF-8 that has a 2-methylimidazolate (MeIM) group as organic linker. The latter has been characterized by Yaghi's group [26]. As reported in the literature its specific surface area (Langmuir surface area) is 1.81m2 g−1, the thermal stability is quite high (up to 823K) that allows its use in catalysis [31]. It has a good chemical resistance and porous structure (pore diameter: 11.6Å) [26], ZIF-8 looked as a potential good candidate as catalyst in ethanolysis of urea for its thermal resistance. In Table 1, Entries 7 and 8, the DEC yield is shown at 7 and 15h of reaction. As Table 1 shows, increasing the time of reaction from 7 to 15h, there is an increment of the DEC yield for ZIF-8. Noteworthy, ZnO gives 17% of DEC yield at 7h (Table 1, Entry 1) and only 4.4% at 15h (Table 1, Entry 2), confirming literature data [14c]. The lower yield may be justified in terms of an alkylating reaction of substrates in which DEC is involved producing N-ethyl ethyl carbamate as main by-product, reaction that may be catalyzed by zinc in homogeneous conditions [14c], but is not by the heterogeneous ZIF-8 catalyst. The measurement of the Zn concentration in solution after 7h and 15h using ZIF-8 shows that only a limited amount of Zn has been transferred to the solution (Table 3). The lower catalytic rate of ZIF-8 with respect to ZnO can be explained in terms of a more difficult accessibility of the Zn centres in crystalline ZIF-8 (Fig. 2 ) with respect to homogeneous Zn catalyst. It must be emphasized that the amount of released Zn in solution in this case is not responsible for the catalytic activity as shown by the fact that the solution is not able to significantly catalyze DEC formation: a check with a concentration of ZnO equal to that generated by the leached Zn from ZIF-8 after 7 and 15h of reaction produces only traces of DEC (≪1%). In order to verify whether the ZIF structure remains unchanged after reaction, XRD (Fig. 3 ) and XPS determinations before and after reaction were carried out. The Bragg-reflections of XRD spectra reported in Fig. 3a are of the structural model of ZIF-8 phase published: ZIF-8 (SOD–methyl derivative). The plot shows that the most of the peaks are well indexed (with the exception of a peak-shift due to instrumental errors) with the Bragg-reflections of the structure published. The only peaks (at 31,768–34,421–36,259 2θ) not indexed by the model structural of ZIF-8 phase published are of the ZnO phase, as shown in Fig. 3b. The recovered catalyst shows, thus, some ZnO in addition to the original ZIF-8. The oxide can be formed by decomposition of the starting catalyst and may remain inglobated into the structure of ZIF-8. In fact, if it was free in solution it would have been converted into the soluble complex Zn(NH3)2(NCO)2. The amount of released ZnO is ≪ 1% of the starting Zn. On the other hand, XPS analyses reveal that the Zn/N ratio on the surface does not change significantly after the use in catalysis (Zn/N=0.5±0.1 before and Zn/N=0.53±0.01 after the use in catalysis) confirming that the minor structural modifications observed in XRD analyses happens only in the bulk so that the catalytic activity is not affected. 3.3 Ethanolysis of urea using Zn-tethered systems as catalysts A third approach to preserve Zn from leaching was to synthesize Zn-tethered systems such as tethered ZnCl2 (Fig. 4 ) and tethered Zn(NCO)2 (Fig. 5 ). The catalytic results are shown in Table 1, Entries 9 and 10. Table 1 shows that the overall “apparent” catalytic activity is lower than that of ZnO but these catalysts show the highest specific activity per Zn-centre. This low yield may be due to the fact that the catalysts behave mostly as a heterogeneous catalysts (Table 4) and the access to Zn-centre may be influenced by the bidentate NN ligand. 3.4 Recoverability study of the catalysts after reaction As anticipated above, because of ZnO solubilization in the reaction medium, it is difficult to make an easy and quantitative recovery of the catalyst after reaction. This makes difficult or impossible the catalyst recycling and the use of flow reactors. Herein, leaching of zinc in the liquid phase has been determined for all the samples via EDX analysis and the results are shown in Tables 2–4 . Table 2 clearly shows that mixed oxides, as well as supported oxides, prevent at a different extent according to their structure, the zinc loss in the liquid phase. CuO/ZnO mixed oxide can be recovered at 80%. The 0.5In2O3/ZnO mixed oxide releases less zinc but is less active. ZIF-8 (Table 3) is quite good from the point of view of stability, recovery and reuse. Tethered Zn on silica using a bidentate ammine ligand (Figs. 3 and 4) affords a system of good stability with a high activity per Zn-centre. Moreover, carrying out the reaction with ZIF-8 for 15h, a high yield in DEC was obtained without observing a significant loss of zinc in the liquid phase and without further conversion of DEC into unwanted products, as observed in the case of soluble ZnO. ZIF-8 behaves as a real heterogeneous catalyst and shows an interesting overall activity better than that of ZnO on the long term. 3.5 Surface characterization N2-physisorption experiments were carried out to determine the BET surface area of the most active heterogeneous catalysts. Table 5 shows that a sample with a high BET surface area could not ensure a substantial increase of its catalytic performance in the production of DEC since it is affected by chemical and structural properties. In case of samples 3 the high value of BET surface could be due to the tridimensional structure of the compound that however, as explained above, hinder the access to the metal centre by the reagent molecules. Samples 4 and 5, in spite of the similar BET surface area, show different catalytic activity thanks to the nature of the substituents on the metal centres. Chemisorptions of CO2 and NH3 following by CO2 and NH3-TPD have been carried out in order to determine the basic/acid properties of the catalysts (Fig. 6 ). Basic catalysts could activate the alcohol molecule via abstraction of H+ [17]. Acid sites could interact with the molecule of ethyl carbamate ones it is formed favouring the nucleophilic attack of the alcoholate. Fig. 6 shows that the used heterogeneous catalysts have very different desorption profiles: in particular, ZIF-8 and tethered ZnCl2 present strong basic and acid sites since the probe-gases are released in both cases from the surface, on average, at T >523K. ZIF-8, which is the most robust catalyst among those that have a good activity in the ethanolysis of urea, shows the strongest basic sites (T >723K) and a higher number of strong acid sites. This suggests that a catalyst with strong acid and basic sites could better catalyze the reaction of DEC production. We have to point out that this is the first time that a finding on such correlation is reported and more data are necessary before statements on the correlations between acid-basic properties and the catalytic activity may be made. These preliminary results are precious indications for catalyst design. 4 Conclusions The newly synthesized Zn-based mixed-oxides catalysts are able to reduce the leaching in the liquid phase of the catalytic metal centre and make the catalyst heterogeneous so that they can be easily recovered and reused in consecutive runs. All the tested catalysts reduce the leaching of Zn in solution with respect to ZnO. ZIF-8 avoids it almost completely and it is the most convenient catalyst in DEC production via ethanolysis of urea. In fact, its catalytic activity increases significantly with time without concomitant loss of zinc. Its surface properties, high BET surface area and high strong basic sites on the surface, may be the drivers of its performance in the production of diethyl carbonate via ethanolysis of urea. Some of the new catalysts (ZIF-8, mainly, but also tethered Zn-complexes) behave as heterogeneous catalysts and thanks to such property they are almost quantitatively recovered and recycled. coredata.dc:description: New Zn-based catalysts are described that act as heterogenized or heterogeneous catalysts, with easy recovery and re-utilization with a limited or even zero Zn-leaching. For stabilizing in the heterogeneous form the catalytically active Zn centre, mixed oxides, ZIF-8 and Zn-tethered systems have been synthesized and found to sensibly reduce the leaching of Zn in solution with respect to ZnO, making possible their recovery and reuse. ZIF-8 can be used for long time of reaction, reaching high DEC yields (comparable or higher than those obtained with ZnO) without any significant loss of zinc.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of diethylcarbonate by ethanolysis of urea: A study on the recoverability and recyclability of new Zn-based heterogeneous catalysts
